description: From New Latin androides, from Ancient Greek ἀνδρός (andrós) (genitive of ἀνήρ (anḗr), “man”) + -ειδής (-eidḗs), itself from εἶδος (eîdos, “form, image, shape, appearance, look”). Note the form ἀνδρώδης (andrṓdēs, “manly”) already existed in Ancient Greek. Surface analysis, andr- +‎ -oid.

adjectives.description: android (comparative more android, superlative most android)

entries.meaning: (anatomy, in pelvimetry) Of the pelvis, having a narrow anterior segment and a heart-shaped brim, typically found in the male.
A robot that is designed to look and act like a human being (not necessarily a male one).
